title: Stakeholder Power & Interest
description: Master the Power/Interest Grid to classify stakeholders into 4 quadrants and tailor engagement strategies based on power types
objectives: Classify stakeholders using the Power/Interest Grid into 4 quadrants: Manage Closely, Keep Satisfied, Keep Informed, Monitor
Identify stakeholder power types (Legitimate, Expert, Referent, Persuasive) and their implications for engagement
Tailor communication strategies and engagement levels based on power and interest combinations
Prioritize stakeholders in crisis situations based on power level (high power stakeholders take priority)
Recognize when to reassess stakeholder classifications as project dynamics change

screens.headline: 12 stakeholders. Limited time. Infinite demands. Who gets your attention first?
screens.body: Alex has 8 hours to create a stakeholder management strategy for Savory & Co.'s $200K tasting menu project. Ava (lead investor) demands to see the plan by EOD: 'Not everyone needs weekly meetings. Show me you know how to prioritize.' Dr. Amelia Foster warns: 'The mistake most PMs make? Treating all stakeholders the same. Ava (high power investor) needs close management. Elena (HR coordinator) needs monitoring. Wrong classification = wasted time on low-priority stakeholders while high-power players feel ignored.'

elements: Alex surrounded by 12 stakeholder photos, looking overwhelmed
Empty 2×2 Power/Interest Grid with 4 quadrants labeled

quote.text: Alex, I need a stakeholder strategy by EOD. I don't have time for 12 weekly status meetings. Show me who gets your attention and why.

screens.learningHook: You'll learn: How to classify stakeholders using the Power/Interest Grid. What power types exist (Legitimate, Expert, Referent, Persuasive). How to tailor engagement strategies based on power and interest. How to prioritize in crisis situations. Get it right: efficient stakeholder management, high-power stakeholders feel valued. Get it wrong: project blockers, wasted time, regulatory issues.

content.title: The Power/Interest Grid Framework
content.description: The Power/Interest Grid (also called Stakeholder Salience Model) helps PMs prioritize stakeholder engagement based on two dimensions: POWER (ability to influence project success) and INTEREST (level of concern about project outcomes).

quadrants.label: Keep Satisfied
quadrants.strategy: Minimal communication, meet needs, don't over-engage

quadrants.label: Manage Closely
quadrants.strategy: Frequent meetings, involve in decisions, close collaboration

quadrants.label: Monitor
quadrants.strategy: Minimal effort, check occasionally for changes

quadrants.label: Keep Informed
quadrants.strategy: Regular updates, proactive communication, don't over-manage

content.pmbokReference: PMBOK 7th Ed, page 12 (Stakeholder Engagement Assessment Matrix)
content.keyInsight: Not all stakeholders need the same level of engagement. Match engagement strategy to power and interest levels.

content.title: Stakeholder Power Types
content.description: Understanding WHERE a stakeholder's power comes from helps you tailor your engagement approach.

powerTypes.definition: Power derived from official role or position in the organization
examples: Ava Thompson (Lead Investor) - Controls budget approval
Inspector Lee (Health & Safety Regulator) - Legal authority to shut down operations
Carlos Mendez (General Manager) - Executive decision-making authority
powerTypes.engagementImplication: Respect formal processes, use official communication channels, document decisions

powerTypes.definition: Power derived from specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise
examples: Marco Rossi (Executive Chef) - Culinary expertise and creative vision
Dr. Amelia Foster (PMI Consultant) - Project management expertise
powerTypes.engagementImplication: Defer to their expertise in their domain, solicit their input on technical decisions, acknowledge their knowledge

powerTypes.definition: Power derived from personal qualities, charisma, or reputation that inspire loyalty and admiration
examples: Kiki Chang (Celebrity Food Critic) - Reputation and influence in culinary world
Marco Rossi (Executive Chef) - Respected by kitchen staff, admired for culinary achievements
powerTypes.engagementImplication: Leverage their influence to champion the project, involve them in stakeholder communication, acknowledge their contributions publicly

powerTypes.definition: Power derived from access to information or ability to persuasively communicate ideas
examples: Jordan Kim (Marketing Director) - Controls messaging and public perception
Sam Rodriguez (Finance Manager) - Controls financial reporting and budget visibility
powerTypes.engagementImplication: Provide them with accurate information, involve them in communication strategies, address their concerns with data and rationale

insights.insight: Prioritize by POWER first, then INTEREST
insights.explanation: In crisis situations, high-power stakeholders take priority regardless of interest level. Inspector Lee (high power, low interest) requesting an unscheduled compliance check takes priority over Kiki (high power, high interest) tweeting disappointment. Why? Inspector Lee can shut down operations (non-negotiable power).

Low-power high-interest stakeholders (Sam, Jamie, Devon, Jordan, Rashid) need regular proactive communication, but they DON'T need daily check-ins or decision-making authority. Keep them informed (bi-weekly updates), but don't over-manage.

Stakeholders with Expert Power (Marco) respond well to collaborative decision-making ('What's your culinary vision?'). Stakeholders with Legitimate Power (Ava, Inspector Lee) respond to formal processes and documentation.

If you don't identify and classify stakeholders early, you'll miss critical inputs. Example: Failing to engage Marco (high power chef) early means menu designs won't reflect his vision → rework, delays, budget overruns.

success.message: Solid strategy, Alex. You're managing Marco, Kiki, and me closely—we have high power and high stakes. Inspector Lee and Carlos get minimal updates but their needs are met. Smart prioritization.

needsImprovement.message: Alex, you misclassified several stakeholders. Inspector Lee doesn't need weekly meetings—he only cares about compliance. Elena doesn't need close management—she has no decision-making authority. Review the Power/Interest Grid and try again.

stakeholderFeedback.perfectFeedback: Correct! Ava has high power (budget approval) and high interest (project success). Manage Closely.
stakeholderFeedback.adjacentFeedback: Partial credit. Ava has high power AND high interest. Move from 'Keep Satisfied' to 'Manage Closely.'
stakeholderFeedback.wrongFeedback: Incorrect. Ava has high power and high interest. She should be in 'Manage Closely,' not 'Monitor.'

stakeholderFeedback.perfectFeedback: Correct! Inspector Lee has high power, but his interest is LOW (only compliance). Keep Satisfied.
stakeholderFeedback.adjacentFeedback: Partial credit. Inspector Lee has high power, but his interest is LOW (only compliance). Move from 'Manage Closely' to 'Keep Satisfied.'
stakeholderFeedback.wrongFeedback: Incorrect. Inspector Lee has high power but low interest. He should be in 'Keep Satisfied.'

stakeholderFeedback.perfectFeedback: Correct! Sam has low power (doesn't approve budget) but high interest (tracks closely). Keep Informed.
stakeholderFeedback.adjacentFeedback: Partial credit. Sam has high interest but low power. Move from 'Manage Closely' to 'Keep Informed.'
stakeholderFeedback.wrongFeedback: Incorrect. Sam has low power and high interest. He should be in 'Keep Informed.'

stakeholderFeedback.perfectFeedback: Correct! Elena has low power and low interest. Monitor only.
stakeholderFeedback.adjacentFeedback: Partial credit. Elena has low power AND low interest. Move to 'Monitor.'
stakeholderFeedback.wrongFeedback: Incorrect. Elena has low power and low interest. She should be in 'Monitor,' not 'Manage Closely.'

screens.title: Mid-Project Crisis: Who Do You Prioritize?
screens.context: It's Week 6 of the tasting menu project. Two urgent issues arise simultaneously: (1) Kiki Chang (Celebrity Food Critic) tweets: 'Disappointed to hear Savory & Co. is cutting corners on sourcing. Expected better. #TastingMenuFail' - Impact: Negative publicity, potential reputation damage. (2) Inspector Lee (Health & Safety Regulator) emails: 'I'm conducting an unscheduled compliance inspection tomorrow at 9am. Ensure all documentation is ready.' - Impact: Could shut down operations if non-compliant.
screens.question: You have 2 hours before end of day. Which stakeholder do you prioritize FIRST and WHY?

options.text: Kiki (critic) - Her tweet is public and damaging reputation immediately
options.feedback: ❌ Wrong. Kiki's tweet is a REPUTATION issue (important but not an immediate operational blocker). Inspector Lee has the POWER to shut down operations tomorrow if we fail compliance. Regulatory authority > Public perception in crisis prioritization. Address Inspector Lee first, then Kiki.

options.text: Inspector Lee (regulator) - Regulatory compliance is non-negotiable, failure could shut down operations
options.feedback: ✅ Perfect! You correctly prioritized regulatory compliance (non-negotiable power) over reputation management (important but addressable later). This demonstrates understanding of power prioritization in crisis situations.

options.text: Both equally - Delegate Kiki to marketing, handle Inspector Lee yourself
options.feedback: ⚠️ Partially correct approach (delegating Kiki is smart), but the question asks WHO to prioritize FIRST. Inspector Lee must come first due to regulatory power.

options.text: Neither - Escalate both to Carlos (GM) for decision
options.feedback: ❌ Wrong. Don't escalate prematurely. As PM, you should handle stakeholder prioritization. Inspector Lee comes first (regulatory compliance), then address Kiki's concern.

screens.modelAnswer: Prioritize Inspector Lee FIRST. Here's why: Inspector Lee has HIGH POWER (legal authority to shut down operations) and regulatory compliance is NON-NEGOTIABLE. If we fail the inspection tomorrow, the entire project (and restaurant) could be shut down. Kiki's tweet is concerning, but it's a REPUTATION issue, not an operational blocker. We can address Kiki's concern AFTER securing compliance—perhaps by sharing our sourcing commitments and inviting her to tour the kitchen. Prioritization Rule: In crisis, HIGH POWER stakeholders (especially regulators) take priority over high-interest stakeholders. Compliance > Marketing.

keyPoints: Inspector Lee can shut down operations
Kiki's concern can be addressed after compliance secured

screens.hint: Think about: (1) Which stakeholder has NON-NEGOTIABLE power? (2) What's the consequence of ignoring each stakeholder? (3) Which issue can wait 24 hours and which cannot?

screens.summary: You've learned to classify stakeholders using the Power/Interest Grid (Manage Closely, Keep Satisfied, Keep Informed, Monitor), identify power types (Legitimate, Expert, Referent, Persuasive), and prioritize stakeholders in crisis situations. Effective stakeholder management means tailoring engagement strategies to power and interest levels—not treating all stakeholders the same.
keyTakeaways: Power/Interest Grid: 4 quadrants guide engagement strategies - HIGH POWER + HIGH INTEREST = Manage Closely (frequent meetings, involve in decisions); HIGH POWER + LOW INTEREST = Keep Satisfied (minimal communication, meet needs); LOW POWER + HIGH INTEREST = Keep Informed (regular updates, don't over-manage); LOW POWER + LOW INTEREST = Monitor (minimal effort, check occasionally)
Power types: Legitimate (positional), Expert (knowledge), Referent (admired), Persuasive (informational)
Prioritization: In crisis, prioritize HIGH POWER stakeholders first (regulatory > reputation)
Reassessment: Power and interest change over time—review classifications at major milestones
Early identification: Classify stakeholders early to prevent misalignment and wasted effort

characterThoughts.thought: I see your strategy now, Alex. You're managing the high-power high-interest stakeholders closely, keeping regulators satisfied without over-engaging them, and keeping the operational team informed. This is efficient stakeholder management.

Excellent work. You demonstrated understanding of the Power/Interest Grid, power types, and crisis prioritization. Remember: not all stakeholders need the same attention. Match your engagement to their power and interest levels.

I learned that stakeholder management isn't about treating everyone equally—it's about strategic prioritization. Ava, Marco, and Kiki need close management. Inspector Lee needs to be kept satisfied. The operational team needs regular updates. Elena needs monitoring. That's how you manage 12 stakeholders efficiently.
